page.title: 08History - from 14th Century
page.content: The Monks of Reading soon gave up living on the island but they continued for another 250 years until 1549, to manage and harvest the produce. St Adrian's island was one of the most noted places of pilgrimage in Scotland and the scene of many reputed miracles in the 14th, 15th and 16th centuries. Among its pilgrims were Scottish Kings and Queens. In the early 16th century the island was used as an isolation centre. One of the first lighthouses in Scotland was erected on the Isle by Alexander Cunningham in 1636. There was a village on the May during the 17th and 18th centuries. One of the occupations of the inhabitants was smuggling. The caves around the Island afford excellent places for hiding contraband.
